coref_content: you can spot they at any all - candidate meeting, those engage citizen who have nt make up those engage citizen who have nt make up their mind yet's mind yet. they re the one lean forward in they's seat when the booing or cheering start because they re actually try to hear the answer. they re the one who might applaud briefly after well - consider answer -- but for a different candidate each time. they be the people who be interested not only in what the candidate have to say, but in what the issue be. and they ve give up they's free time to do it. if it be nt for the undecided, all-­candidate meeting would turn into dress rehearsal for question period, as supporter try to out - clap each other no matter how insipid supporter's candidate answer. these public debate could determine which candidate would perform to expectation as backbencher, be able to get through their party talking point without say anything surprising or get flustered. whether that be all we want from prospective mp, I leave to the reader. election be, at least in part, about persuade the undecided. its not just a contest between the red, blue, orange and green partisan on the four corner of your near intersection. the very repetitiveness of election sign that make election sign so annoying lead to name recognition, which help voter research the right candidate. and all sign, public and private, tell voter what riding voter live in by remind voter which candidate be in voter's area. most of all, the sign on public property be a reminder that even now, after all the hard campaigning of the last few week, plenty of voter have nt yet make up plenty of voter's mind. undecided, colloquially, can include a few different category. most strictly, undecided mean the people who really have no clue how the people who really have no clue how they might vote might vote. some have nt even think about vote yet, and some of some wo nt ever think about vote, because some of those people wo nt vote. undecided include the people who be simply stare at the choice before they, wonder when someone go to come in with a hide camera and reassure they that they ve be punke and here be the real platform. the Nanos polling from Sept. 15 put the undecided vote at just under 10 per cent. just under 10 per cent be down from 16.7 per cent at the start of the campaign. but undecided widen to roughly half the electorate if we include the people who say the people who say they re go to vote for one party but be willing to consider a second choice re go to vote for one party but be willing to consider a second choice. these be the uncommitted, the waffler between two party, the people wait to see which choice seem to serve the people's strategic purpose, or which platform have the big clunker. uncommitted voter be the reason we have campaign. some people get involve in politic by join or support political party, but join be not the only form of engagement. in conversation about election, people keep confide to I that people have nt make up people's mind. people say it quietly, almost apologetically, as if it a task people have nt get around to yet. but there be still a month leave in the campaign. you do nt have to decide until you do. in a close election in which no one party have yet persuade more than half of Canadians, party will be tempt to play to the base, to demonize the other side, to polarize issue that should have cross - partisan appeal, to get the decide voter angry and afraid so the decide voter ll get out and vote. undecided voter counter this tendency, because to capture undecided voter, party have to reach beyond party's traditional talking point and fear - mongering. be undecided, four week from election day, be nt a personal failing. be a sign of an open mind, and an open mind s good for the country.
